comments.content:
Flexible NetFlow extends the capabilities of traditional NetFlow by allowing the collection of Layer 2 header information. 

Search for "match datalink" or "Layer 2" attributes:

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/lan/catalyst9300/software/release/16-5/configuration_guide/nmgmt/b_165_nmgmt_9300_cg/b_165_nmgmt_9300_cg_chapter_01000.html

Netflow is only "IP traffic flows" not Layer2
Only B,E are correct

discussion.content:
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/ios-nx-os-software/flexible-netflow/index.html

Cisco IOS Flexible NetFlow benefits:

Flexibility and scalability of flow data beyond traditional NetFlow
Customized traffic identification ( B )
Ability to focus and monitor specific network behavior
Ability to monitor a wider range of packet information, producing new information about network behavior ( look like C )
Enhanced network anomaly and security detection
Convergence of multiple accounting technologies into one accounting mechanism. ( E )

So its B,C,E

Selected Answer: BE
Cisco IOS Flexible NetFlow benefits:

 Flexibility and scalability of flow data beyond traditional NetFlow
 Customized traffic identification
 Ability to focus and monitor specific network behavior
 Ability to monitor a wider range of packet information, producing new information about network behavior
 Enhanced network anomaly and security detection
 Convergence of multiple accounting technologies into one accounting mechanism

discussion.content:
C & E

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/ios-nx-os-software/flexible-netflow/index.html

choices.E: They converge multiple accounting technologies into one accounting mechanism.
choices.C: They provide monitoring of a wider range of IP packet information from Layer2 to 4.
choices.D: They provide attack prevention by dropping the traffic.
choices.A: They provide accounting and billing enhancements.
choices.B: They allow the user to configure flow information to perform customized traffic identification.

questions.question_text: What are two benefits of Flexible NetFlow records? (Choose two.)

An engineer needs to configure a Cisco Secure Email Gateway (SEG) to prompt users to enter multiple forms of identification before gaining access to the SEG.
The SEG must also join a cluster using the preshared key of cisc421555367. What steps must be taken to support this?

choices.A: Enable two-factor authentication through a RADIUS server, and then join the cluster via the SEG GUI.
choices.D: Enable two-factor authentication through a TACACS+ server, and then join the cluster via the SEG GUI.
choices.C: Enable two-factor authentication through a RADIUS server, and then join the cluster via the SEG CLI
choices.B: Enable two-factor authentication through a TACACS+ server, and then join the cluster via the SEG CLI.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C - joining via CLI
ESA and SEG semm to have exactly the same process for joining the cluster. These cisco articles are specific for SEG:
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/security/esa/esa14-0/user_guide/b_ESA_Admin_Guide_14-0/b_ESA_Admin_Guide_12_1_chapter_0101000.html#con_1122185
Creating and Joining a Cluster

You cannot create or join a cluster from the Graphical User Interface (GUI). You must use the Command Line Interface (CLI) to create, join, or configure clusters of machines.

comments.content:
These are Troubleshooting steps for SEG when joining the cluster fails:
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/security/secure-email-gateway/221658-troubleshoot-failure-to-join-seg-to-clus.pdf
The article references the Cluster Configuration article for ESA for more information about the process. So, SEG and ESA use the same steps for building the cluster.

he clusterconfig Command

A machine can create or join a cluster only via the clusterconfig command. 

Same process as in ESA:
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/security/email-security-appliance/200885-ESA-Cluster-Requirements-and-Setup.html#toc-hId-1251782448

discussion.content: A is correct. Joining cluster is from GUI (its configuration is in CLI)

Selected Answer: C
C is correct:

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/security/email-security-appliance/200885-ESA-Cluster-Requirements-and-Setup.html#toc-hId-1251782448

comments.content: SEG is not ESA, that is the key

Yes, Radius is sure:
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/security/esa/esa15-0/user_guide/b_ESA_Admin_Guide_15-0/b_ESA_Admin_Guide_12_1_chapter_0100001.html

The email gateway provides two methods for adding user accounts: creating user accounts on the email gateways itself, and enabling user authentication using your own centralized authentication system, which can be either an LDAP or RADIUS directory. 
The userconfig > twofactorauth command in the CLI. See the CLI Reference Guide for AsyncOS for Cisco Secure Email Gateway.
C is correct. Only Radius is supported. Cluster configuration is only via CLI

discussion.content: Q211 same question with conflicting answer!! Any suggestions?

choices.D: supports VMware vMotion on VMware ESXi

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
The Cisco Web Security Virtual Appliance (WSAv) is a virtualized version of the Cisco Web Security Appliance (WSA). The unique characteristic of WSAv compared to a physical WSA is that it supports VMware vMotion, which allows live migration of the virtual appliance between VMware ESXi hosts without downtime.

Selected Answer: A
A) additional license (no additional costs for customers with active WSA license, however, still need to complete additional licensing steps, as described below)
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/collateral/security/web-security-appliance/data_sheet_C78-727788-1.html

Selected Answer: D
You can use VMware® VMotion™ to migrate a running virtual appliance to a different physical host. Page 21
https://www.cisco.com/c/dam/en/us/td/docs/security/content_security/virtual_appliances/Cisco_Content_Security_Virtual_Appliance_Install_Guide.pdf

Selected Answer: D
It's D.
"You can use VMware® VMotionTM to migrate a running virtual appliance to a different physical host."
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/security/wsa/wsa-va-install-guide/virtual-appliance-install-guide.pdf

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
It's A. 
 "...Automatic VMotion is currently not supported in Secure Web Appliance."
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/security/wsa/wsa-va-install-guide/virtual-appliance-install-guide.pdf

Selected Answer: A
Correct Answer is A:

The Cisco Secure virtual appliance requires an additional license to run the virtual appliance on a host. You can use this license for multiple, cloned virtual appliances. Licenses are hypervisor-independent

https://www.cisco.com/c/dam/en/us/td/docs/security/content_security/virtual_appliances/Cisco_Content_Security_Virtual_Appliance_Install_Guide.pdf

Selected Answer: A
A - ...seriously D make no sense besides what already has been mentioned

A Cisco WSAv (Web Security Virtual Appliance) is a virtualized version of the Cisco Web Security Appliance, which provides web security, filtering, and control capabilities. Compared to a physical appliance, the WSAv can be deployed on a virtualization platform such as VMware ESXi or Microsoft Hyper-V.

One characteristic that is unique to a WSAv is that it requires an additional license for deployment on a virtualization platform. This license is called the Virtual Web Security Appliance License (VWSA), which allows customers to deploy the virtual appliance on a virtualization platform.

Selected Answer: A
The Virtual Appliance License page 26
The Cisco Secure virtual appliance requires an additional license to run the virtual appliance on a host.
You can use this license for multiple, cloned virtual appliances. Licenses are hypervisor-independent.

https://www.cisco.com/c/dam/en/us/td/docs/security/content_security/virtual_appliances/Cisco_Content_Security_Virtual_Appliance_Install_Guide.pdf

Selected Answer: A
The correct answer is A. We use VMware Vmotion to migrate a running virtual appliance to a different physical host. 
However, The Cisco Secure virtual appliance requires an additional license to run the virtual appliance on a host. You can use this license for multiple, cloned virtual appliances. Licenses are hypervisor-independent.
Go to Page 24 and 26 
https://www.cisco.com/c/dam/en/us/td/docs/security/content_security/virtual_appliances/Cisco_Content_Security_Virtual_Appliance_Install_Guide.pdf

Selected Answer: AD
Deployment models and scale

Cisco Secure Workload offers both Software-as-a-Service (SaaS) and on-premises options allowing customers to choose the model that meets their business needs.

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/collateral/data-center-analytics/tetration-analytics/datasheet-c78-737256.html

Selected Answer: AD
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/collateral/data-center-analytics/tetration-analytics/datasheet-c78-737256.html

Selected Answer: AD
https://www.cisco.com/site/us/en/products/security/secure-workload/index.html

Selected Answer: D
D & E:
According to Cisco, the two workload security models are:

D. On-premises: This model refers to workloads that are hosted on servers that are physically located within the organization's premises. This model allows the organization to have complete control over the infrastructure and security of the servers hosting the workloads.

E. IaaS (Infrastructure as a Service): This model refers to workloads that are hosted on a cloud infrastructure, where the organization is responsible for securing the operating system and the applications running on the infrastructure. In this model, the organization has control over the security of the workloads, but not the underlying cloud infrastructure.

Selected Answer: AD
A & D are correct

AD is correct, see link provided by Mjestic
